summary: This document is an email chain from January 2020 between FBI personnel and CBS News producers regarding a 60 Minutes story about Jeffrey Epstein's death. The FBI maintains a 'no comment' stance on the ongoing investigation while CBS seeks clarification on details like surveillance camera functionality, the autopsy, and the position of Epstein's body.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased inmate and accused sex trafficker
persons.context: The subject of the 60 Minutes investigation and the FBI's ongoing death investigation. His suicide in custody is the central topic.

persons.name: Oriana Zill
persons.context: CBS News producer who sent detailed questions to the FBI regarding the investigation into Epstein's death, seeking an off-the-record briefing or on-the-record responses.

persons.name: Emily Gordon
persons.context: CBS News correspondent who coordinated with the FBI National Press Office to discuss the 60 Minutes story on Epstein.

persons.name: Jagerson
persons.context: FBI press officer who communicated with CBS News, relayed the 'no comment' stance, and provided information about searching FBI records.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: One of the two correctional officers charged in connection with Epstein's death, mentioned in a question about whether federal investigators had interviewed them.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: One of the two correctional officers charged in connection with Epstein's death, mentioned in a question about whether federal investigators had interviewed them.

persons.name: Sharyn Alfonsi
persons.context: 60 Minutes correspondent copied on the email from producer Oriana Zill to the FBI.

persons.name: Daniel Novack
persons.context: Attorney mentioned in a referenced article as having filed a pro bono FOIA lawsuit that led to the release of an FBI report on Epstein.

connections.description: Both are correctional officers charged in the federal case related to Epstein's death, referenced together in the CBS questions.
Both are CBS News producers working together on the 60 Minutes story about Epstein's death.
FBI press officer corresponding with CBS producer regarding media inquiries about the Epstein death investigation.
FBI press officer corresponding with CBS reporter regarding the Epstein story and document requests.

events.title: 60 Minutes Epstein Story Airs
events.description: CBS News' 60 Minutes airs a story investigating the circumstances around Jeffrey Epstein's death, including cell photos from the autopsy.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The document references the ongoing investigation into his death.

events.title: FBI Probe Closed
events.description: Referenced in a linked article, a federal FBI investigation into Epstein was closed after he 'provided information to the FBI as agreed upon'.

locations: 524 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019 (CBS News Office)
keyFacts: The FBI maintained a consistent 'no comment' policy regarding the ongoing investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death in January 2020.

CBS News/60 Minutes was pursuing specific unanswered questions about Epstein's death, including the functionality of surveillance cameras on his tier, the position of his body when found, and whether the charged correctional officers had been interviewed about the death itself.
The email chain reveals CBS News had obtained cell photos from Epstein's autopsy for their story.
The document references a prior federal case against correctional officers Michael Thomas and Tova Noel in connection with Epstein's death.
A past FBI report, released via FOIA, indicated Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution deal was secured after he 'provided information to the FBI'.
